column1: Six weeks since trip and I can barely walk. Severe joint pain, nausea, fatigue, swelling. There is no cure or treatment. There were NO NOTICES that this awful disease was on the island. No postings in hotel or stores. They don't want their tourism effected. The family practice at Red Hook is seeing people so ill with this they are being brought in to the clinic in wheelchairs. It is not worth seeing any of this island to have this awful devastating illness now.
What are you speaking of! Please say! We will be down there in 3 wks

Check out travel advisories for the Carribbean. Chickguinea virus is spread by mosquitoes that are covering the islands. There is no vaccination or cure. I have never dealt with such terrible joint pain. I could not even open my eyes for three days. Nausea, fatigue. It has been over 5 weeks and I am still very ill. I have gotten vitamin C iv's for treatment, but really that's all there is. I wouldn't ever go back there and I wouldn't trust mosquitoe repellent either. I don't want to be a bad news person, but I can tell you I am afraid that I will not be able to afford the time it is taking me to get better. Tourism in islands don't want to tell you about it, because you might change plans. Many cruise lines are losing customers because of this. Check out the CDC we site. The cases at clinics on the islands are huge.

Alli1976: It is actually called chikungunya and is a virus spread by mosquitoes and is similar to Dengue Fever. Chikungunya has been in the USVI for less than a year and is also in Florida now. When you go to the USVI or anywhere in the tropics, it is recommended that you use mosquito repellent to avoid being bitten, preferably one with DEET. Here is a link to the CDC website with more info.:…cdc.gov/travel/…chikungunya-caribbean

I arrived in the Cyril King airport in St Thomas yesterday. A person was handing out warning flyers to each arriving passenger with detailed information on protection from mosquito bites, and clear warnings about the virus. I am sorry it won't help you, but it may be some comfort to know that every effort is being made to warn other travelers to take steps to protect themselves.

Thank you so much for posting this. I just really wanted to get the word out about this awful virus. I should have been more aware myself and used precautions. Yesterday I had to start prednisone to try to combat the severe arthritic symptoms of this virus. It is very debilitating and so far no real cure.

Titirocks, I am so sorry that you are suffering with this disease and hope the prednisone will help. I do have to disagree with you regarding notification. My family and I were there in July. I must say that I am a firm believer that when travelling it is my responsibility to be aware of any issues that may arise while I am away!The info about Chik V was all over the tripadvisor forum, the cdc website and the VI Now forums - I made sure to travel with tons off deep woods off this trip!!I am sorry that you didn't do your homework - the info was out there. Get well soon!

I know I was negligent in doing the research as it was a quick trip. Just had no idea and saw no notices while I was there. Believe me, I am beating myself up for not checking beforehand as this virus is awful. Thanks for your kind thoughts.

If you know you were negligent maybe you should stop complaining on the forum. Most people know when they go to the tropics that they need to use protection from mosquitoes. It is probably time to give this a rest.

People, you need to do your research! The message below has been the very prominent heading of the National Park Service website for over 9 months (we went in May and it was up months before that while we were doing our planning!) Always, always search for travel alerts regarding where you are intending to travel. All that said, a bottle of DEET will save you a lot of trouble and let you enjoy true paradise. Mosquito Borne DiseaseThere are two mosquito transmitted diseases (virus), Dengue, and Chikungunya Fever, now confirin in the Virgin Islands. For more information on the disease and it's prevention please take a look at this link. More »

If one is reconsidering going to the Caribbean because of this new-found knowledge you may also need to consider relocating. Check out the distribution map of the common carriers since it may soon be coming to a town near you.cdc.gov/chikungunya/…CHIKV_VectorControl.pdf From what I've heard from people that have gotten one or the other, if given a choice I'd take my chances with a case of the Chickungunya virus over Lyme's disease and so far that hasn't restricted my travel.

thank you!

However, she said that all visitors may not have received the flyer because they opted not to accept it from the greeter."
Great news! I honestly cant imagine vacationing anywhere else !! Thanks all !

I agree with Stacy B., do your research on the places you're traveling to especially on the CDC website. Assume that tropical diseases will be present if you're traveling to those regions. My cousin and I took the precaution of always applying bug spray especially at night during our recent trip to St. John. I mentioned to her that it seems everyone's forgotten that Dengue Fever is around since Chikungunya hit the headlines. She joked that Chikungunya's so last season and it's the new Dengue. It was not said to diminish the seriousness of either tropical disease but said with concern that people forget there are other illnesses besides Chikungunya that can be contracted in the tropics. We were relieved that during the trip, only I got mosquito bites and only a few, at that. We were very concerned about both diseases and took the necessary precaution of applying bug spray. I feel for anyone who has gotten a mosquito-borne disease as the property manager of where we stayed was fighting Chikungunya while we were there :(

You make a good point. All of this talk about Chikungunya and Dengue really isn't coming up that often. Neither virus is fun, but since Chhikungunya is new to this area, it has gotten a lot of press. Dengue has been here pretty much forever, and will likely always be here. And unlike Chikungunya, you can get it more than once, and there are different strains of it as well. So bug spray, keeping covered, keeping away from mosquitoes, is ALWAYS a good idea. It's best to just be informed the best as you can no matter where you travel. We have other things here that people may not know about as well, fire coral, sea urchins, jelly fish, christmas bush, etc…. So you should also not be touching things you know nothing about either. There are certain risks you take when you don't educate your self, and this thread is a great reminder to us all to do our homework.
